newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Plans to cut U.S. soy crush unsurprising - Sparks.
newsitem.headline: Plans to cut U.S. soy crush unsurprising - Sparks.

text.p: Announcements by several U.S. soybean crushers that they will temporarily some capacity take out of the market are seasonally normal and should not distract from long-term expansion plans, a Sparks Inc official said.

U.S. crush capacity was forecast to rise by 20 percent by the end of 1998 so the industry could meet demand growth and keep its share in the world market, Rob Westmoreland, Sparks executive vice president, said at an oilseeds conference.
"The latest announcements sound interesting to the market but the shortfall should be taken up by Latin American availability," he said.
Westmoreland said crushers were perhaps taking the opportunity to achieve higher prices before the arrival of Latin American crops exerted price pressure.

An announcement by ADM on Wednesday that one plant would be shut and three others run on reduced rates followed on from Cargill Inc announcing that three of its plants would be shut for some time this summer.
Westmoreland said European feeds industry demand would be more crucial to the market than U.S. capacity changes over the next few months.
Further ahead, Chinese protein demand should fuel oilseeds demand, not least because China had $100 billlion in foreign exchange reserves.
"If they choose to close their food gap, they've got the money," Westmoreland said.
Feed-intensive pig and broiler numbers in China were rising and protein meals demand of 20 million tonnes-plus this year might rise to 22 million in 1998.
